EXPERIENCES OF MR. JOHN R. BULLARD IN HAVANA, 1901
IN CONNECTION WITH THE U.S. ARMY YELLOW FEVER BOARD AND EXPERIMENTAL YELLOW FEVER.
(As told by Mr. Bullard to Dr. P. S. Hench in St. Augustine, April 16, 1941.
To be corrected and amplified by Mr. Bullard, July, 1941.)

Foreword: "Mr. John R. Bullard, native of Massachusetts, a graduate
of Harvard University where he was a distinguished athlete, and later on engaged in farming
in Cuba, volunteered and was infected with yellow fever by the injection of blood.
He became sick October 23, 1901 "(From Senate Doc. 822, p. 28). For the official
record of Mr. Bullard's case see article “The Etiology of Yellow Fever--A Supple-
mental Note” by Reed and Carroll originally published in American Medicine, 3:
301-305; Feb. 22, 1902; also published in Senate Doc. 822, Chapt. 7, p. 156 (case
IX--J.R.B.) and pp. 158-159 (Case X--erroneously labelled case of J.M.B. instead
of J.R.B.). On October 15, 1901, Bullard was given a subcutaneous injection of
infected serum filtrate. A transient febrile reaction occurred on October 19
but no yellow fever developed. On October 22, 1901, he was given a subcutaneous
injection of infected blood and on October 23 developed experimental yellow fever.

Mr. Bullard never met Walter Reed; the latter had left Cuba inon February 9,
or March, 1901. Carroll returned to Havana October, 1901 to do some supplementary
experiments. Since Carroll was still acting as a member of the U. S. Army Yellow
Fever Board the work done by Carroll (including the experiments on Bullard) was
reported with Reed as coming from the board. (Comment of P.S.H.--Why wasn't
Agramonte's name listed as co-author?) Hence Bullard's case was officially among
those studied by the board and he was therefore eligible for the honors (medal
and annuity) later voted by Congress. However, since his case belongs to Carroll's
late series (October, 1901) Bullard's name (and that of the others of Carroll's
October, 1901 series) is often not listed by writers who only consider the cases
of the fall of 1900 and the spring of 1901. P.S.H.
Hench--2--ds
Mr. Bullard's own story (to be corrected and amplified by him).

I was born at Dedham, Massachusetts, July 5, 1872. In September 18942 when I entered
went to Harvard; My family livedschool and social life had been in Boston. I was a member of the Harvard crews
of 1894, 1895 and 1896, being captain in 1895 and 1896. (The only other Harvard
crewman who ever became captain for two years was my younger brother, Harold, name?
who was captain in 1901 and 1902.) I graduated from Harvard academic (2) coursewith an A. B. degree
in June 1896 and that fall decided not to continue at the Law School in spite of my father's
wishes,
who was a
Boston lawyer.entered Harvard Law School but did not enjoy my studies
and 1894 law school after two months. I met a man in Boston who offered me aowned
job in Mexico on a coffee plantation in Mexico and invited me to visit him. I workedwas there from January to June 1897

But after 65 months in Mexico I tired of the life and workthe prospects had no appeal and I
took a steamer for BostonNew York via Havana. Enroute to Havana I became very ill and
when my boat entered the harbor of Havana the physician of the port who was none
other than “dear old Dr. Carlos Finlay” (this was in June 1897) wanted me to disembark
and enter a hospital in Havana. But I was so anxious to get home thatas Habana was a pest-hole at that time I refused
and stayed aboard only after assuming full responsibility in case I should die
enroute to BostonNew York. Thereafter I was sick most of the time for three years of what
was found in 1899 to be amebic dysentery. During these three years (1897-18991900)
I lived part time in BostonDedham, part time in Bermuda where I washad under lease a farm ofsmall potatoes
and lilies.y farm. I was cured completely onby the spring of 18991901. About that timeIn 1900 my father, a
Boston lawyer, died.

In the fall of 1901 I felt I couldn't stand Boston anymorelonger as I was
fed up with my life therewith many things and distracted by a personal grief, so I decided to go
to Cuba, buy a farm and settle down permanently there. I landed in CubaHabana in September
by 1901, a few days after the assassination of President McKinley. OnAfter arrivingal in
Havana I went to visitcalled on Major Jefferson R. Kean who withand Mrs. Kean waswho were living dth
their two children in the “officers row” of houses at Columbia Barracks, Quemados,
Cuba, a few miles west of Habana. I had previously known the Major and his wife (the first Mrs. Kean) who had been Louise
Hench--3--ds
Young, the daughter of my mother's first cousin. Major Kean had met Miss Young
at St. Augustine, Florida. Major and Mrs. Kean invited me to visit them to live at their home until Iwhenever
should start out to hunt for a farm to purchase.I cared to. After a very few days I set out
and while hunting for a farm in Artemisa in the province of Pinar del Rio, I de-
veloped malaria about September 10, 1901 and by at once returned to the home of Major Kean
while I was ill of malaria. Dr. (Major) Kean had Dr. Carroll see me and it was de-
cided that I had probably gotten my malaria by exposure while onat a house party inon
Cape Cod just prior to leaving for Havana. (Comment--Isn't that a long incubation
period?) (Search me!)

While convalescing from my malaria at Major Kean's home I frequently was
present when Kean and Carroll, the latter a constant visitor at the Kean house,
discussed Carroll's yellow fever experiments. In the evenings Carroll often stopped
in to discuss his cases of experimental yellow fever. Having become somewhat fam-
iliar with Dr. Carroll's work I decided to get an immunizing dose of yellow fever
from Dr. Carroll so that I could stay in Cuba without further interruption of my
career. I had already changed occupations and habitations several times and was
determined to make a real go of it this time in Cuba. Volunteering to Dr. Carroll
for experimental yellow fever was, I can assure you, a cold blooded business proposi-
tion. There were no heroics in it as far as I was concerned. Although the recent
experiments of Reed, Carroll and their associates had strongly incriminated the
mosquito as the cause of yellow fever nobody yet knew at that time (October, 1901)
that yellow fever would really be eradicated from Cuba; I suspected that I would
probably get it spontaneously anyhow, so I decided I'd rather have it under the most favorable
circumstances viaand Carroll's expert care; country doctors were still killing many by diagnosing
yellow fever as malaria and
giving large doses of guinine.immunizing dose.

But I had a hard time persuading Dr. Carroll to use me. After he had put turned
me downoff several times, (Mr. Bullard, please amplify) one evening Dr. Carroll turned
to Major Kean and said, “What do you suppose this young man wants? He wants us to
use him as an experimental case so that he may became
immune to yellow fever and not have to worry about it any
further out in the country.

Why did Major Kean think it foolish? He knew the
importance of the experiments. Perhaps he thought enough had been
done?

Major Kean “gave me hell” telling metried to dissuade me, saying he thought I was very foolish (Mr. Bullard, why?
please amplify). But Dr. Carroll finally agreed to take me on. So on October 15,
1901 I went to the “General WardWood Laboratory” on Calzada de la RomaReina in Havana.
This was a government laboratory where Carroll was raising his mosquitoes at that
time. There I met two army privates, Paul Hamann and Albert W. Covington who had
also volunteered for Dr. Carroll's experiments and We three men sat in a row while
Dr. Carroll injected us with infected serum under our shoulder blades.

(Mr. Bullard, please note a discrepancy here between your story and the
official record. You infer that all three of you received your injections at the
same time, i.e. almost simultaneously the same hour. But the record (Senate Doc.
822, p. 156,) says Hamann was injected 11 A.M. October 15, Covington at 11:05 A.M.
October 15 and yourself at 2:30 P.M. that day. Perhaps the three of you sat to-
gether in an outer office; they were injected in the morning but for some reason
your injection was postponed till after lunch. How about this?)

I do not understand
this at all; better use
my amendment which is harmless.
Carroll, Hamann

After receiving their injections Hamann and Covington returned to their
No, what was known as the Santa Clara Battery in El Vedado.
stations (I suppose you mean at Camp Columbia). After receiving my injection I
went at once (how? By yourself, by train or in an ambulance?)was taken in an army passenger waggon drawn by mules out to one of the
yellow fever wards at Columbia Barracks. I was quarantined in one of the little
buildings which made up these wards. My recollection is that in October, 1901
these yellow fever wards consisted of about six small shacks; some hold only two
beds, others held several beds. Each shack had a complicated double entrance,
double doors protected by permanent mosquito netting. These shacks were beside
the La Playa Railroad track. When I was there I do not believe there wereremember any tents
used for yellow fever cases. I remained in one of these little buildings (two beds
or more?) night and day. An army contract surgeon, Mazzuri from New Orleans was - charge of the camp. Dr. Carroll came to see twice a dayus daily, and Major Kean
often called. AboutOn the thirdfourth day of my quarantine ( about October 18) [the
records say it was October 19] I heard an ambulance pull up outside. Without permission I went out
Hench--5--ds
to see if I could help the orderlywith the litters and there I found that the occupants of the
ambulance were none other than my two fellow volunteers, Hamann and Covington,
who had come down with yellow fever! This gave me quite “a kick”. I admit I felt
rather excited, and promptly developed a rapid pulse and a mild feverrise in temperature. But these
soon passed off. Obviously I didn't have yellow fever although I don't know yet
why they got it and I did not.

If you were quarantined how was it you were allowed
outside, & later helped around the wards? What was the
extent of your quarantine? Observation and confinement to the Yellow Fever Camp.

The next few days I remained under quarantine and kept myself occupied
by helping the orderlies at the yellow fever shacks. Major Kean tried to make me believe that decided I must be
a natural immune and advisedwanted me to return to his house but I said, “Hell, no!
I'm only half way through this.” So I persuaded Dr. Carroll to give me an in-
jection of blood to test my supposed immunity, which he drew from Hamann. (Covington's blood test was such that Dr. Carroll
wouldn't give me any of Covington's blood.) I had this injection on October 22.
Next day I came down with yellow fever. I had a “mild case” and wasn't officially
very sick but it was bad enough. I had headaches, pains and tenderness in my
abdomen, mild jaundice and albuminuria. I was cared for in the same “yellow fever
ward”, one of the several small wooden buildings I have mentioned as being beside
the La Playa railroad track. I recall the little old bridge across this track
for I crossed it (when, Mr. Bullard?). after discharge and I passed under it many times
when going from Quemados to the Playa or r.r. train.
Amplify?

On the third day of my illness the Havana Yellow Fever Board came out from Habana
to see me.us. It included Drs. Agramonte and Finlay. I remember Dr. Finlay best especially
because of the following incident. When Dr. Finlay came into the room and saw me
he promptly said, “I have seen you before” and then Finlayhe recalled that heI
(Bullard) was the young fellow whom he had seen four years before sick on a boat
in Havana harbor; he did not remember my name.

After the acute phase of my illness I returned to Major Kean's house
to recuperate for a few days and then returned to Artemeisa in my search for a
farm. There Iand bought a farm and raisedplanted tobacco for three and a half years. Then
in 1905 I went into the real estate business with officesheadquarters in Havana till 1909
Hench--6--ds
when with a partnerfriend and I boughtacquired a small sugar plantation “Central Armonia,” at Bolondron in
Matanzas Province. In 1911 I entered the employ of The Cuba Company, a large holding
sugar company of whichand I became Vice President in 1924.5 of its sugar subsidiary Compañia Cu-
bana. I left Cuba in 1929 because
of ill health and have not returned since. I have retired from business and have
lived in St. Augustine since 1933.

(In 1929-1930 Mr. Bullard was a patient for several months at the Mayo
Clinic. He stayed at The Kahler, met Mr. Kahler, my wife's father, and was enter-
tained a couple of times in Mr. Kahler's home. Mr. Bullard recalls meeting me in
Rochester and recognized me at once when I visited him in St. Augustine on
April 16, 1941. - P.S.H.)

Addenda. Mr. Bullard never saw Camp Lazear nor Military Hospital No. 1.
(Why bring this in?)
He only visited Las Animas Hospital once (for what reason?). He knew nothing as to
whether Moran or Kissinger volunteered first. He had never met Miss Maas. He
did not know exactly where Lazear died but he distinctly remembered that the first
Mrs. Kean told him that she and others were convinced that Lazear had been bitten
on purpose. Bullard's case belongs to Carroll's late series (October, 1901) and
was not listed in Guiteras' series. Bullard did not know personally any of those
who participated in the earlier experiments of Lazear, Reed, Carroll or Agramonte.
He stated that the brief data about him in the article “Honor the Memory of Heroes...”
etc. (page 6) was correct. He had a few clippings re three or four volunteers who
had died and very kindly gave them to me. He had no other data except the early
photographs of himself taken in 18954 (?) and in 1901, copies of which he kindly
gave me.
